itemDescription: women's rights activist and theosophist, editor

wikipedia_page.main: Frances Henrietta Müller (1846 – 4 January 1906) was a Chilean-British women's rights activist and theosophist.

response: There were political, religious, and cultural debates about women's suffrage in the various countries.Carolina Barry, ed. Sufragio feminino: Prácticas y debates políticos, religiosos, y culturales en la Argentina y América Latina. Caseros, Argentina: Editorial de la Universidad Nacional de Tres de Febrero 2011.  Important advocates for women's suffrage include Hermila Galindo (Mexico), Eva Perón (Argentina), Alicia Moreau de Justo (Argentina), Julieta Lanteri (Argentina), Celina Guimarães Viana (Brazil), Ivone Guimarães (Brazil), Henrietta Müller (Chile), Marta Vergara (Chile), Lucila Rubio de Laverde (Colombia), María Currea Manrique (Colombia), Josefa Toledo de Aguerri (Nicaragua), Elida Campodónico (Panama), Clara González (Panama), Gumercinda Páez (Panama), Paulina Luisi Janicki (Uruguay), Carmen Clemente Travieso, (Venezuela).
*Henrietta Müller (1846–1906) – Chilean-British women's rights activist and theosophist

The Woman's Signal was a weekly British feminist magazine published by Marshall & Son, London, from 4 January 1894 to 23 March 1899.Johns Hopkins University Libraries It was edited by Lady Henry Somerset, Annie Holdsworth and Florence Fenwick-Miller.Feminist and Women's Periodicals at Stanford  Although primarily a temperance paper, it dealt with several feminist issues including fair wages.The Morris Society It began life as The Women's Penny Paper (27 October 1888 – 27 December 1890), edited by Helena B Temple (Henrietta Müller), later becoming The Woman’s Herald (3 January 1891 – 28 December 1893). In 1892, Mrs Frank Morrison became editor, followed by Christina Bremner, then by Lady Henry Somerset in 1893.Adam Matthew Publications It was bought out by Lady Henry and renamed The Woman's Signal. Florence Fenwick-Miller bought the paper in 1895 and was the editor and sole proprietor until its demise in 1899.Elizabeth Crawford (1999) The Women's Suffrage Movement: A Reference Guide, 1866-1928, UCL Press, London

link_mentions.page: List of members of the London School Board

response: Established in 1882, and initially located in Byng Place, It initially catered for female students (having been co-founded by educationalist and suffragist Annie Leigh Browne, Mary Stewart Kilgour, Mary Browne (Lady Lockyer) and Henrietta Müller)Jane Martin, ‘Browne, Annie Leigh (1851–1936)’, Oxford Dictionary of National Biography, Oxford University Press, 2004 accessed 12 Jan 2017 The first Principal was Eleanor Grove who arranged for lease of the house in Byng Place, assisted by Rosa Morison, who volunteered to take the posts with no salary. College Hall was incorporated into the University of London in 1910. It moved to nearby Malet Street in 1932.

In 1880 she and Mary Stewart Kilgour campaigned for women's education; their work (with inputs from Mary Thomasina Browne - later Lady Lockyer - and Henrietta Müller) and Browne's money led to the opening of College Hall in Byng Place in 1882. It later (1932) moved to nearby Malet Street.
In 1882, Kilgour collaborated with Annie Leigh Browne, Browne's sister Mary (later Lady Lockyer) and Henrietta Müller to found College Hall, London.

Eva Maria Müller was born in 1852. She was the younger daughter of German businessman William Müller, and his English wife, Maria Henrietta. One of Eva's sisters, Henrietta Müller, was also a notable suffragist.
